"In reality, however, “Viral” is a laboratory-perfect example of how not to write about a scientific issue. The authors rely less on the scientists doing the painstaking work to unearth the virus’ origin than on self-described sleuths who broadcast their dubious claims, sometimes anonymously, on social media. ...

Some of it is.  
Researchers depend on grants from governments, societies, institutions such as colleges and universities, and wealthy individuals for funding.  If the research doesn't show what is expected or desired then the scientists can expect that some of their funding will be pulled. This is a very strong incentive for the researchers to try and push their findings in a way that will provide the best benefit for themselves and their research, which is not always the best for science or the people.

Oh the old "they just want grants!" this is hysterical.

If all they cared about was money, they would quit research immediately. Private industry gives more money and better hours. Nobody goes into research to get money or an easy job, as that's the opposite of what you'll get.

Firstly, I didn't say that all they cared about is money.  I pointed out where their money comes from. If they were just after making large sums of money I am sure that they could do far better in the private sector, but that rarely comes with the notoriety and public prestige that comes with doing research in a "public" setting, ie. major universities or hospitals, especially if they are the department head.  This can be a major driving factor why some go into research, to get a paper published with their name on it.  
Secondly, most lead researchers have staffs and undergrades who do most of the late night work and the tedious jobs of comparing and compiling results, and yes I've been around many people who do research in many areas from electrical engineering to physics so I do know what I am talking about.
Thirdly, I don't discount or diminish what good researchers do.  I am merely pointing out what it takes for them to be able to do their work and the pressures that they can face and that some can be swayed to provide the desired results.

Ha, no, sorry :D Anyone who tries the 'they just want their grants' is talking out of their rear no matter how they try and twist it. The peer review process exists for a reason and again, no matter how hard you try.

The money is in the private sector. :D 

Oh? You've been around people who do research? Fascinating, because I actually work in it, and see what happens.

So you are a researcher, then let me ask where does the funding come from for the work you do?  Grants?  University endowments? Trusts left by alumni? The funding for your time and research has to come from somewhere because I highly doubt that you are working for free and research in either the public or private sectors is very expensive.  Second question.  What happens to that funding if your research is found to be wrong or faulty?  Does it not get withheld or revoked?  
Again I am not trying to diminish or discount the work of good researchers, either public or private.
